scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains records from the Workers Solidarity Alliance, anarchist periodicals and a small amount of printed ephemera.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights for publicity and privacy) held by the Workers Solidarity Alliance, the creator of this collection, were transferred to New York University in 2011. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Donated by Steven Rabinowitz on behalf of the Workers Solidarity Alliance in 2011. The accession number 2011.136 is associated with this gift.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Workers Solidarity Alliance (WSA) is an anti-capitalist, anti-authoritarian organization. Founded in 1984 from a pre-existing network including the Libertarian Workers' Group, the WSA advocates for self-organzined mass organizations in the workplace and in struggles outside the workplace. The journal Ideas and Action, founded in 1982, was published by WSA between 1984 and 1997. In 2010 Ideas and Action was relaunched as a web publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Workers Solidarity Alliance is an anti-capitalist, anti-authoritarian organization of activists who believe that working people can build a new society and a better world based on the principles of solidarity and self-management. WSA also publishes ideas and action, which was created in July, 1981 as an independent anarcho-syndicalist semi-annual print magazine. After Workers Solidarity Alliance was founded in November, 1984, ideas and action became the magazine of WSA (with issue #5), and continuing through the publication of issue #17 in 1997. It now exists as a blog on the WSA website.
